title: isMounted
content: Do not use isMounted. eslint: react/no-is-mounted Why? isMounted is an anti-pattern, is not available when using ES6 classes, and is on its way to being officially deprecated.

title: Official Typescript Documentation
content: Familiar With TypeScript already? The starting point for learning TypeScript TypeScript Best Practices‚Ää-‚ÄäSemicolons and Spacing

title: General
content: No Unused Expressions We shouldn't have unused expressions in our code. If we have them, we should remove them. Copy // Bad üëé a + b; // Good üëç let add = a + b; Filename Name files with camelCase. Reason: Conventional across many JS teams. Copy accordion.tsx myControl.tsx stringUtils.ts map.ts

title: Variables and Function
content: Use camelCase for variable and function names Reason: Conventional JavaScript Copy // Bad üëé varFooVar; functionBarFunc(){} // Good üëç var fooVar; functionbarFunc(){} No Unused Variables @typescript-eslint/no-unused-vars Likewise, if we have unused variables, then we should remove them. Copy // Bad üëé var num1 =10; var num2 =7; var result = num1 +7; // Good üëç var num1 =10; var result = num1 +7; // Good üëç var num1 =10; var num2 =7; var result = num1 + num2; Don‚Äôt Use Variables Before they‚Äôre Defined With variables that are declared with¬†var we can reference the variable before they‚Äôre defined, but the value will be¬†undefined. This is because the variable is hoisted. let and¬†const solve this problem since they aren‚Äôt hoisted. Therefore, we should use¬†let or¬†const variables. This way, if we reference those variables, we‚Äôll get an error. Copy // Bad üëé var hoisted; console.log(hoisted);// will be undefined; // Good üëç let notHoisted; const alsoNotHoisted; console.log(notHoisted);// Will throw an error (which is what we want in this case); console.log(alsoNotHoisted);// Will also throw an error (which is what we want in this case); Replace Magic Numbers with Named Constants @typescript-eslint/prefer-as-const If we have numbers that are used as constants repeatedly but aren‚Äôt assigned to a constant, then we should assign it to one. This way, we can change it once and the value will be reflected everywhere. Also, named constants tell us the meaning of the number. Therefore, instead of writing: Copy // Bad üëé enumFoo{ bar =1} // Good üëç constNUMBER_OF_BARS=1; enumFoo{ bar =NUMBER_OF_BARS} Don‚Äôt Use async if await isn‚Äôt Used Inside the Function @typescript-eslint/require-await We should use¬†async¬†functions only if we have to¬†await¬†something inside it. For instance, if we have something like: Copy // Bad üëé constfoo=async()=>"bar"; // Good üëç constfoo=async()=>{ const url ="some.domain.com"; let response =awaitfetch(url,{ method:'GET' }); } then we should use a normal function. Return Awaited Values Consistently We should not have¬†return¬†and¬†await¬†on the same line since the promises may not have resolved yet. Instead, put them on separate lines. The only exception to this is that we can put¬†return¬†and¬†await¬†on the same line inside a¬†try¬†block to catch errors from another promised-based function Copy // Bad üëé asyncfunctionfoo(){ returnawaitbar(); } // Good üëç asyncfunctionfoo(){ const val =awaitbar(); return val; } // Good üëç asyncfunctionfoo(){ try{ returnawaitbar(); }catch(error){} }

title: Array
content: Annotate arrays as foos:Foo[] instead of foos:Array<Foo>. Reasons: Its easier to read. Its used by the TypeScript team. Makes easier to know something is an array as the mind is trained to detect []. Copy // Bad üëé foos:Array<Foo>; // Good üëç foos:Foo[];

title: Strings
content: Prefer single quotes (') unless escaping. Reason: More JavaScript teams do this (e.g. airbnb, standard, npm, node, google/angular, facebook/react). Its easier to type (no shift needed on most keyboards). Prettier team recommends single quotes as well Double quotes are not without merit: Allows easier copy paste of objects into JSON. Allows people to use other languages to work without changing their quote character. Allows you to use apostrophes e.g. He's not going.. But I'd rather not deviate from where the JS Community is fairly decided. Copy // bad üëé var foo ="bad"; // good üëç var foo ='bar'; When you can't use double quotes, try using back ticks (`). @typescript-eslint/restrict-template-expressions Reason: These generally represent the intent of complex enough strings. Copy // good üëç var foo =`this foo has a dynamic ${bar}`; Have Consistent Use of Backticks, Double Quotes or Single Quotes We should use backticks or quotes in a consistent manner for declaring strings. Better yet, we should use backticks since they‚Äôll create template strings, which are more flexible. They allow expressions to be embedded in it.

title: Class
content: Use PascalCase for class names. Reason: This is actually fairly conventional in standard JavaScript. Copy // Bad üëé classfooBoo{} // Good üëç classFooBoo{} Use camelCase of class members and methods Reason: Naturally follows from variable and function naming convention. Copy // Bad üëé classFoo{ BarVar:number; BazFunc(){} } // Good üëç classFoo{ barVar:number; bazFunc(){} } No Useless Constructors @typescript-eslint/no-useless-constructor We shouldn‚Äôt have useless constructors. Copy // Bad üëé classA{ constructor(){ } } // Bad üëé classBextendsA{ constructor(value){ super(value); } } They‚Äôre both redundant so they should be removed.

title: Interface
content: Use PascalCase for name. Reason: Similar to class Copy // Bad üëé interfacethemeProps{ color:string; } // Good üëç interfaceThemeProps{ color:string; } Use camelCase for members. Reason: Similar to class Copy // Bad üëé interfaceColorProps{ FirstColor:string; second-color:string; } // Good üëç interfaceColorProps{ firstColor:string; secondColor:string; } Don't prefix with I Reason: Unconventional. lib.d.ts defines important interfaces without an I (e.g. Window, Document etc). Copy // Bad üëé interfaceIFoo{ } // Good üëç interfaceFoo{ }

title: Type
content: Use PascalCase for name. Reason: Similar to class Copy // Bad üëé type infoBaseProps ='htmlFor'|'className'|'children'|'id'; // Good üëç typeInfoBaseProps='htmlFor'|'className'|'children'|'id'; Use camelCase for members. Reason: Similar to class Copy // Bad üëé typeAnimal={ animalrace:string } // Good üëç typeAnimal={ animalRace:string }

title: Type vs. Interface
content: Use type when you might need a union or intersection: Copy // Good üëç typeFoo=number|{ someProperty:number} Use interface when you want extends or implements e.g Copy // Good üëç interfaceFoo{ foo:string; } interfaceFooBarextendsFoo{ bar:string; } classXimplementsFooBar{ foo:string; bar:string; }

title: Namespace
content: Use PascalCase for names Reason: Convention followed by the TypeScript team. Namespaces are effectively just a class with static members. Class names are PascalCase => Namespace names are PascalCase Copy // Bad üëé namespace fooBaz { } // Good üëç namespaceFooBaz{ } Enum# Use PascalCase for enum names Reason: Similar to Class. Is a Type. Copy // Bad üëé enum colorOne { } // Good üëç enumColorOne{ } Use PascalCase for enum member Reason: Convention followed by TypeScript team i.e. the language creators e.g SyntaxKind.StringLiteral. Also helps with translation (code generation) of other languages into TypeScript Copy // Bad üëé enumColor{ redHue } // Good üëç enumColor{ RedHue }

title: Null vs. Undefined
content: Prefer not to use either for explicit unavailability Reason: these values are commonly used to keep a consistent structure between values. In TypeScript you use types to denote the structure Copy // Bad üëé let foo ={ x:123, y:undefined }; // Good üëç let foo:{ x:number, y?:number}={ x:123}; Use undefined in general (do consider returning an object like {valid:boolean,value?:Foo} instead) Copy // Bad üëé returnnull; // Good üëç return undefined; Use null where its a part of the API or conventional Reason: It is conventional in Node.js e.g. error is null for NodeBack style callbacks. Copy // Bad üëé cb(undefined) // Good üëç cb(null) Use truthy check for objects being null or undefined Copy // Bad üëé if(error ===null) // Good üëç if(error) Use == null / != null (not === / !==) to check for null / undefined on primitives as it works for both null/undefined but not other falsy values (like '',0,false) e.g. Copy // Bad üëé if(error !==null)// does not rule out undefined // Good üëç if(error !=null)// rules out both null and undefined

title: Tabs vs. Spaces
content: Use tabs over spaces. Reason: Use tabs for indenting your code. With tabs users can choose their desired width. This has positive implications for accessibility and screenreaders, putting people in control of how they want to view the code. Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(){ ‚àô‚àôlet name; } // bad üëé functionbar(){ ‚àôlet name; } // good üëç functionbaz(){ ‚àô let name; }

title: Semicolons
content: Use semicolons. Reasons: The usage of semicolons is a core value of our community. Consider the points of the opposition, but be a traditionalist when it comes to abusing error correction mechanisms for cheap syntactic pleasures. Explicit semicolons helps language formatting tools give consistent results. Missing ASI (automatic semicolon insertion) can trip new devs. Copy // Bad üëé let x =5 // Good üëç let x =5; We should put in semicolons in our code instead of letting the JavaScript interpreter add them for us in unexpected places. Remove Useless Semicolons @typescript-eslint/no-extra-semi We should remove duplicate semicolons in our code. We only need one semicolon at the end of a statement. Copy // Bad üëé let x =5;; // Good üëç let x =5; Require Semicolons Instead of Automatic Semicolon Insertion Instead of letting the Javascript interpreter put in semicolons for us, we should put them in ourselves. Copy // Bad üëé functionreturnObject(){ return//<-----semi colon will be inserted causing an error. { key: value }; } // Good üëç functionreturnObject(){ return{ key: value }; }

title: Tabs for Indentation
content: Use tabs for indenting your code. With tabs users can choose their desired width. This has positive implications for accessibility and screenreaders, putting people in control of how they want to view the code.

title: Newlines
content: Use UNIX-style newlines (\n), and a newline character as the last character of a file. Windows-style newlines (\r\n) are forbidden inside any repository.

title: No trailing whitespace
content: Always clean up any trailing whitespace in your .js files before committing.

title: Use semicolons
content: According to scientific research, the usage of semicolons is a core value of our community. Consider the points of the opposition, but be a traditionalist when it comes to abusing error correction mechanisms for cheap syntactic pleasures.

title: 100 characters per line
content: Limit your lines to 100 characters.

title: Use single quotes
content: Use single quotes, unless you are writing JSON. This helps you separate your objects' strings from normal strings. Copy // bad üëé var foo ="bad"; // good üëç var foo ='bar'; Opening braces go on the same line, Your opening braces go on the same line as the statement. Copy // bad üëé if(true) { console.log('losing'); } // good üëç if(true){ console.log('winning'); } Also, notice the use of whitespace before and after the condition statement. What if you want to write 'else' or 'else if' along with your 'if'... Copy // bad üëé if(true) { console.log('losing'); } elseif(false) { console.log('this is bad'); } else { console.log('not good'); } // good üëç if(true){ console.log('winning'); }elseif(false){ console.log('this is good'); }else{ console.log('finally'); }

title: Declare one variable per var statement
content: Declare one variable per var statement, it makes it easier to re-order the lines. Copy // bad üëé var keys =['foo','bar'], values =[23,42], object ={}, key; // good üëç var keys =['foo','bar']; var values =[23,42]; var object ={};

title: Use tabs
content: eslint: indent Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(){ ‚àô‚àôlet name; } // bad üëé functionbar(){ ‚àôlet name; } // good üëç functionbaz(){ ‚àô let name; }

title: Space Before Blocks
content: Place 1 space before the leading brace. eslint: space-before-blocks Copy // bad üëé functiontest(){ console.log('test'); } // good üëç functiontest(){ console.log('test'); } // bad üëé dog.set('attr',{ age:'1 year', breed:'Bernese Mountain Dog', }); // good üëç dog.set('attr',{ age:'1 year', breed:'Bernese Mountain Dog', });

title: Keyword Spacing
content: Place 1 space before the opening parenthesis in control statements (if, while etc.). Place no space between the argument list and the function name in function calls and declarations. eslint: keyword-spacing Copy // bad üëé if(isJedi){ fight(); } // good üëç if(isJedi){ fight(); } // bad üëé functionfight(){ console.log('Swooosh!'); } // good üëç functionfight(){ console.log('Swooosh!'); }

title: Space Around Infix Operators
content: Set off operators with spaces. eslint: space-infix-ops Copy // bad üëé const x=y+5; // good üëç const x = y +5;

title: End of File
content: End files with a single newline character. eslint: eol-last Copy // bad üëé import{ es6 }from'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; // ... exportdefault es6; Copy // bad üëé import{ es6 }from'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; // ... exportdefault es6;‚Üµ ‚Üµ Copy // good üëç import{ es6 }from'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; // ... exportdefault es6;‚Üµ

title: Chained Calls
content: Use indentation when making long method chains (more than 2 method chains). Use a leading dot, which emphasizes that the line is a method call, not a new statement. eslint: newline-per-chained-calleslint: no-whitespace-before-property Copy // bad üëé $('#items').find('.selected').highlight().end().find('.open').updateCount(); // bad üëé $('#items'). find('.selected'). highlight(). end(). find('.open'). updateCount(); // good üëç $('#items') .find('.selected') .highlight() .end() .find('.open') .updateCount(); // bad üëé const leds = stage.selectAll('.led').data(data).enter().append('svg:svg').classed('led',true) .attr('width',(radius + margin)*2).append('svg:g') .attr('transform',`translate(${radius + margin},${radius + margin})`) .call(tron.led); // good üëç const leds = stage.selectAll('.led') .data(data) .enter().append('svg:svg') .classed('led',true) .attr('width',(radius + margin)*2) .append('svg:g') .attr('transform',`translate(${radius + margin},${radius + margin})`) .call(tron.led); // good üëç const leds = stage.selectAll('.led').data(data);

title: Padding
content: Blank Lines# Leave a blank line after blocks and before the next statement. Copy // bad üëé if(foo){ return bar; } return baz; // good üëç if(foo){ return bar; } return baz; // bad üëé const obj ={ foo(){ }, bar(){ }, }; return obj; // good üëç const obj ={ foo(){ }, bar(){ }, }; return obj; // bad üëé const arr =[ functionfoo(){ }, functionbar(){ }, ]; return arr; // good üëç const arr =[ functionfoo(){ }, functionbar(){ }, ]; return arr; Padded Blocks# Do not pad your blocks with blank lines. eslint: padded-blocks Copy // bad üëé functionbar(){ console.log(foo); } // bad üëé if(baz){ console.log(qux); }else{ console.log(foo); } // bad üëé classFoo{ constructor(bar){ this.bar= bar; } } // good üëç functionbar(){ console.log(foo); } // good üëç if(baz){ console.log(qux); }else{ console.log(foo); } No Multiple Blank Lines# Do not use multiple blank lines to pad your code. eslint: no-multiple-empty-lines Copy // bad üëé classPerson{ constructor(fullName, email, birthday){ this.fullName= fullName; this.email= email; this.setAge(birthday); } setAge(birthday){ const today =newDate(); const age =this.getAge(today, birthday); this.age= age; } getAge(today, birthday){ // .. } } // good üëç classPerson{ constructor(fullName, email, birthday){ this.fullName= fullName; this.email= email; this.setAge(birthday); } setAge(birthday){ const today =newDate(); const age =getAge(today, birthday); this.age= age; } getAge(today, birthday){ // .. } }

title: Spacing
content: Parentheses Spacing# Do not add spaces inside parentheses. eslint: space-in-parens Copy // bad üëé functionbar(foo){ return foo; } // good üëç functionbar(foo){ return foo; } // bad üëé if( foo ){ console.log(foo); } // good üëç if(foo){ console.log(foo); } Inside Brackets# Do not add spaces inside brackets. eslint: array-bracket-spacing Copy // bad üëé const foo =[1,2,3]; console.log(foo[0]); // good üëç const foo =[1,2,3]; console.log(foo[0]); Inside Curly Braces# Add spaces inside curly braces. eslint: object-curly-spacing Copy // bad üëé const foo ={clark:'kent'}; // good üëç const foo ={ clark:'kent'}; Max Length# Avoid having lines of code that are longer than 100 characters (including whitespace). Note: long strings are exempt from this rule, and should not be broken up. eslint: max-len Why? This ensures readability and maintainability. Copy // bad üëé const foo = jsonData && jsonData.foo&& jsonData.foo.bar&& jsonData.foo.bar.baz&& jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux&& jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux.xyzzy; // bad üëé $.ajax({ method:'POST', url:'https://airbnb.com/', data:{ name:'John'}}).done(()=>console.log('Congratulations!')).fail(()=>console.log('You have failed this city.')); // good üëç const foo = jsonData && jsonData.foo && jsonData.foo.bar && jsonData.foo.bar.baz && jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux && jsonData.foo.bar.baz.quux.xyzzy; // good üëç $.ajax({ method:'POST', url:'https://airbnb.com/', data:{ name:'John'}, }) .done(()=>console.log('Congratulations!')) .fail(()=>console.log('You have failed this city.')); Block Spacing# Require consistent spacing inside an open block token and the next token on the same line. This rule also enforces consistent spacing inside a close block token and previous token on the same line. eslint: block-spacing Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(){returntrue;} if(foo){ bar =0;} // good üëç functionfoo(){returntrue;} if(foo){ bar =0;} Comma Spacing# Avoid spaces before commas and require a space after commas. eslint: comma-spacing Copy // bad üëé var foo =1,bar =2; var arr =[1,2]; // good üëç var foo =1, bar =2; var arr =[1,2]; Computed Property Spacing# Enforce spacing inside of computed property brackets. eslint: computed-property-spacing Copy // bad üëé obj[foo ] obj['foo'] var x ={[ b ]: a} obj[foo[ bar ]] // good üëç obj[foo] obj['foo'] var x ={[b]: a } obj[foo[bar]] Function Spacing# Avoid spaces between functions and their invocations. eslint: func-call-spacing Copy // bad üëé func(); func (); // good üëç func(); Key Spacing# Enforce spacing between keys and values in object literal properties. eslint: key-spacing Copy // bad üëé var obj ={ foo :42}; var obj2 ={ foo:42}; // good üëç var obj ={ foo:42}; Trailing Spaces# Avoid trailing spaces at the end of lines. eslint: no-trailing-spaces Multiple Empty Lines# Avoid multiple empty lines, only allow one newline at the end of files, and avoid a newline at the beginning of files. eslint: no-multiple-empty-lines Copy // bad üëé - multiple empty lines var x =1; var y =2; // bad üëé - 2+ newlines at end of file var x =1; var y =2; // bad üëé - 1+ newline(s) at beginning of file var x =1; var y =2; // good üëç var x =1; var y =2;

title: Primitives
content: When you access a primitive type you work directly on its value. stringnumberbooleannullundefinedsymbolbigint Copy const foo =1; let bar = foo; bar =9; console.log(foo, bar);// => 1, 9 Symbols and BigInts cannot be faithfully polyfilled, so they should not be used when targeting browsers/environments that don't support them natively.

title: Complex:
content: When you access a complex type you work on a reference to its value. objectarrayfunction Copy const foo =[1,2]; const bar = foo; bar[0]=9; console.log(foo[0], bar[0]);// => 9, 9

title: Use const for all of your references:
content: avoid using var. eslint: prefer-const, no-const-assign IMPORTANCE: This ensures that you can't reassign your references, which can lead to bugs and difficult to comprehend code. Copy // bad üëé var a =1; var b =2; // good üëç const a =1; const b =2;

title: Use let instead of var.
content: If you must reassign references, use 'let' instead of 'var'. eslint: no-var IMPORTANCE: let is block-scoped rather than function-scoped like var. Copy // bad üëé var count =1; if(true){ count +=1; } // good üëç , use the let. let count =1; if(true){ count +=1; }

title: Block Scoped
content: Note that both let and const are block-scoped. Copy // const and let only exist in the blocks they are defined in. { let a =1; const b =1; } console.log(a);// ReferenceError console.log(b);// ReferenceError

title: No New Object
content: Use the literal syntax for object creation. eslint: no-new-object Copy // bad üëé const item =newObject(); // good üëç const item ={};

title: Computed Property Names
content: Use computed property names when creating objects with dynamic property names. IMPORTANCE: They allow you to define all the properties of an object in one place. Copy functiongetKey(k){ return`a key named ${k}`; } // bad üëé const obj ={ id:5, name:'Lorem Ipsum', }; obj[getKey('enabled')]=true; // good üëç const obj ={ id:5, name:'Lorem Ipsum', [getKey('enabled')]:true, };

title: Object Method Shorthand
content: Use object method shorthand. eslint: object-shorthand Copy // bad üëé const atom ={ value:1, addValue:function(value){ return atom.value+ value; }, }; // good üëç const atom ={ value:1, addValue(value){ return atom.value+ value; }, };

title: Property Value Shorthand
content: Use property value shorthand. eslint: object-shorthand IMPORTANCE: It is shorter and descriptive. Copy const lukeSkywalker ='Lorem Ipsum'; // bad üëé const obj ={ lukeSkywalker: lukeSkywalker, }; // good üëç const obj ={ lukeSkywalker, };

title: Shorthand Property Grouping
content: Group your shorthand properties at the beginning of your object declaration. IMPORTANCE: It's easier to tell which properties are using the shorthand. Copy const newyorkSubway ='Newyork Subway'; const newjerseyTransit ='NewJersy Transit'; // bad üëé const obj ={ episodeOne:1, twoJediWalkIntoACantina:2, newjerseyTransit, episodeThree:3, mayTheFourth:4, newyorkSubway, }; // good üëç const obj ={ newjerseyTransit, newyorkSubway, episodeOne:1, twoJediWalkIntoACantina:2, episodeThree:3, mayTheFourth:4, };

title: Quote Props
content: Only quote properties that are invalid identifiers. eslint: quote-props IMPORTANCE: In general we consider it subjectively easier to read. It improves syntax highlighting, and is also more easily optimized by many JS engines. Copy // bad üëé const bad ={ 'foo':3, 'bar':4, 'data-blah':5, }; // good üëç const good ={ foo:3, bar:4, 'data-blah':5, };

title: Object.prototype Methods
content: Do not call Object.prototype methods directly, such as hasOwnProperty, propertyIsEnumerable, and isPrototypeOf. eslint: no-prototype-builtins IMPORTANCE: These methods may be shadowed by properties on the object in question - consider { hasOwnProperty: false } - or, the object may be a null object (Object.create(null)). Copy // bad üëé console.log(object.hasOwnProperty(key)); // good üëç console.log(Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(object, key)); // best const has =Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty;// cache the lookup once, in module scope. console.log(has.call(object, key)); /* or */ import has from'has';// https://www.npmjs.com/package/has console.log(has(object, key));

title: Object Spread Operator
content: Prefer the object spread operator. over Object.assign to shallow-copy objects. Use the object rest operator to get a new object with certain properties omitted. Copy // very bad üëéüëé const original ={ a:1, b:2}; const copy =Object.assign(original,{ c:3});// this mutates `original` √†¬≤ _√†¬≤ delete copy.a;// so does this // bad üëé const original ={ a:1, b:2}; const copy =Object.assign({}, original,{ c:3});// copy => { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 } // good üëç const original ={ a:1, b:2}; const copy ={...original, c:3};// copy => { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 } const{ a,...noA }= copy;// noA => { b: 2, c: 3 }

title: No Array Constructor
content: Use the literal syntax for array creation. eslint: no-array-constructor Copy // bad üëé const items =newArray(); // good üëç const items =[];

title: Use Arraypush
content: Array#push instead of direct assignment to add items to an array. Copy const someStack =[]; // bad üëé someStack[someStack.length]='abracadabra'; // good üëç someStack.push('abracadabra');

title: Array Spreads
content: Use array spreads ... to copy arrays. Copy // bad üëé const len = items.length; const itemsCopy =[]; let i; for(i =0; i < len; i +=1){ itemsCopy[i]= items[i]; } // good üëç const itemsCopy =[...items]; Use Spreads for Iterable Object# To convert an iterable object to an array, use spreads ... instead of Array.from Array.from. Copy const foo =document.querySelectorAll('.foo'); // good üëç const nodes =Array.from(foo); // best const nodes =[...foo];

title: Using Array.from
content: Array.from for converting an array-like object to an array. Copy const arrLike ={0:'foo',1:'bar',2:'baz', length:3}; // bad üëé const arr =Array.prototype.slice.call(arrLike); // good üëç const arr =Array.from(arrLike); Mapping over Iterables# Use Array.from instead of spread ... for mapping over iterables, because it avoids creating an intermediate array. Copy // bad üëé const baz =[...foo].map(bar); // good üëç const baz =Array.from(foo, bar);

title: Array Callback Return
content: Use return statements in array method callbacks. It's ok to omit the return if the function body consists of a single statement returning an expression without side effects, following 8.2. eslint: array-callback-return Copy // good üëç [1,2,3].map((x)=>{ const y = x +1; return x * y; }); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((x)=> x +1); // bad üëé - no returned value means `acc` becomes undefined after the first iteration [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5],].reduce((acc, item, index)=>{ const flatten = acc.concat(item); }); // good üëç [[0,1],[2,3],[4,5],].reduce((acc, item, index)=>{ const flatten = acc.concat(item); return flatten; }); // bad üëé inbox.filter((msg)=>{ const{ subject, author }= msg; if(subject ==='Mockingbird'){ return author ==='Harper Lee'; }else{ returnfalse; } }); // good üëç inbox.filter((msg)=>{ const{ subject, author }= msg; if(subject ==='Mockingbird'){ return author ==='Harper Lee'; } returnfalse; });

title: Line Breaks for Array Brackets
content: Use line breaks after open and before close array brackets if an array has multiple lines Copy // bad üëé const arr =[ [0,1],[2,3],[4,5], ]; const objectInArray =[{ id:1, },{ id:2, }]; const numberInArray =[ 1,2 ]; // good üëç const arr =[[0,1],[2,3],[4,5]]; const objectInArray =[ { id:1, }, { id:2, }, ]; const numberInArray =[ 1, 2 ];

title: Use Object Destructuring
content: Use object destructuring when accessing and using multiple properties of an object. eslint: prefer-destructuring IMPORTANCE: Destructuring saves you from creating temporary references for those properties. Copy // bad üëé functiongetFullName(user){ const firstName = user.firstName; const lastName = user.lastName; return`${firstName}${lastName}`; } // good üëç functiongetFullName(user){ const{ firstName, lastName }= user; return`${firstName}${lastName}`; } // best functiongetFullName({ firstName, lastName }){ return`${firstName}${lastName}`; }

title: Use Array Destructuring
content: eslint: prefer-destructuring Copy const arr =[1,2,3,4]; // bad üëé const first = arr[0]; const second = arr[1]; // good üëç const[first, second]= arr;

title: Multiple Return Values
content: Use object destructuring for multiple return values, not array destructuring. IMPORTANCE: You can add new properties over time or change the order of things without breaking call sites. Copy // bad üëé functionprocessInput(input){ // then a miracle occurs return[left, right, top, bottom]; } // the caller needs to think about the order of return data const[left, __, top]=processInput(input); // good üëç functionprocessInput(input){ // then a miracle occurs return{ left, right, top, bottom }; } // the caller selects only the data they need const{ left, top }=processInput(input);

title: Single Quotes
content: Use single quotes '' for strings. eslint: quotes Copy // bad üëé const name ='Capt. Janeway'; // bad üëé - template literals should contain interpolation or newlines const name =`Capt. Janeway`; // good üëç const name ='Capt. Janeway';

title: Broken Strings
content: Strings that cause the line to go over 100 characters should not be written across multiple lines using string concatenation. IMPORTANCE: Broken strings are painful to work with and make code less searchable. Copy // bad üëé const errorMessage ='This is a super long error that was thrown because \ of Batman. When you stop to think about how Batman had anything to do \ with this, you would get nowhere \ fast.'; // bad üëé const errorMessage ='This is a super long error that was thrown because '+ 'of Batman. When you stop to think about how Batman had anything to do '+ 'with this, you would get nowhere fast.'; // good üëç const errorMessage = 'This is a super long error that was thrown because of Batman. When you stop to think about how Batman had anything to do with this, you would get nowhere fast.';

title: Prefer Template Strings
content: When programmatically building up strings, use template strings instead of concatenation. eslint: prefer-templatetemplate-curly-spacing IMPORTANCE: Template strings give you a readable, concise syntax with proper newlines and string interpolation features. Copy // bad üëé functionsayHi(name){ return'How are you, '+ name +'?'; } // bad üëé functionsayHi(name){ return['How are you, ', name,'?'].join(); } // bad üëé functionsayHi(name){ return`How are you, ${name}?`; } // good üëç functionsayHi(name){ return`How are you, ${name}?`; }

title: No Eval
content: Never use eval() on a string, it opens too many vulnerabilities. eslint: no-eval

title: No Useless Escapes
content: Do not unnecessarily escape characters in strings. eslint: no-useless-escape IMPORTANCE: Backslashes harm readability, thus they should only be present when necessary. Copy // bad üëé const foo =''this' is \'quoted\''; // good üëç const foo =''this' is \'quoted\''; const foo =`my name is '${name}'`;

title: Function Style
content: Use named function expressions instead of function declarations. eslint: func-style IMPORTANCE: Function declarations are hoisted, which means that it's easy - too easy - to reference the function before it is defined in the file. This harms readability and maintainability. Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(){ // ... } // bad üëé constfoo=function(){ // ... }; // good üëç // lexical name distinguished from the variable-referenced invocation(s) constshort=functionlongUniqueMoreDescriptiveLexicalFoo(){ // ... };

title: Wrap Immediately Invoked Functions
content: Wrap immediately invoked function expressions in parentheses. eslint: wrap-iife IMPORTANCE: An immediately invoked function expression is a single unit - wrapping both it, and its invocation parens, in parens, cleanly expresses this. Note that in a world with modules everywhere, you almost never need an IIFE. Copy // immediately-invoked function expression (IIFE) (function(){ console.log('Welcome to the Internet. Please follow me.'); })();

title: No Loop Functions
content: Never declare a function in a non-function block (if, while, etc). Assign the function to a variable instead. eslint: no-loop-func

title: A function declaration is not a statement.
content: Copy // bad üëé if(currentUser){ functiontest(){ console.log('Nope.'); } } // good üëç let test; if(currentUser){ test=()=>{ console.log('Yup.'); }; }

title: Parameters and Arguments
content: arguments# Never name a parameter arguments. This will take precedence over the arguments object that is given to every function scope. Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(name, options, arguments){ // ... } // good üëç functionfoo(name, options, args){ // ... } Prefer Rest Params# Never use arguments, opt to use rest syntax ... instead. eslint: prefer-rest-params IMPORTANCE: ... is explicit about which arguments you want pulled. Copy // bad üëé functionconcatenateAll(){ const args =Array.prototype.slice.call(arguments); return args.join(''); } // good üëç functionconcatenateAll(...args){ return args.join(''); } Default Parameter Syntax# Use default parameter syntax rather than mutating function arguments. Copy // really bad functionhandleThings(opts){ // No! We shouldn't mutate function arguments. // Double bad: if opts is falsy it'll be set to an object which may // be what you want but it can introduce subtle bugs. opts = opts ||{}; // ... } // still bad functionhandleThings(opts){ if(opts ===void0){ opts ={}; } // ... } // good üëç functionhandleThings(opts ={}){ // ... } Parameter Side Effects# Avoid side effects with default parameters. IMPORTANCE: They are confusing to reason about. Copy var b =1; // bad üëé functioncount(a = b++){ console.log(a); } count();// 1 count();// 2 count(3);// 3 count();// 3 Default Parameters Last# Always put default parameters last. Copy // bad üëé functionhandleThings(opts ={}, name){ // ... } // good üëç functionhandleThings(name, opts ={}){ // ... } Never Mutate Parameters.# eslint: no-param-reassign IMPORTANCE: Manipulating objects passed in as parameters can cause unwanted variable side effects in the original caller. Copy // bad üëé functionf1(obj){ obj.key=1; } // good üëç functionf2(obj){ const key =Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(obj,'key')? obj.key:1; } Never Reassign Parameters.# eslint: no-param-reassign IMPORTANCE: Reassigning parameters can lead to unexpected behavior, especially when accessing the arguments object. It can also cause optimization issues, especially in V8. Copy // bad üëé functionf1(a){ a =1; // ... } functionf2(a){ if(!a){ a =1;} // ... } // good üëç functionf3(a){ const b = a ||1; // ... } functionf4(a =1){ // ... }

title: No New Function
content: Never use the Function constructor to create a new function. eslint: no-new-func IMPORTANCE: Creating a function in this way evaluates a string similarly to eval(), which opens vulnerabilities. Copy // bad üëé var add =newFunction('a','b','return a + b'); // still bad var subtract =Function('a','b','return a - b');

title: Function Spacing
content: Spacing in a function signature. eslint: space-before-function-parenspace-before-blocks IMPORTANCE: Consistency is good, and you shouldn't have to add or remove a space when adding or removing a name. Copy // bad üëé constf=function(){}; constg=function(){}; consth=function(){}; // good üëç constx=function(){}; consty=functiona(){};

title: Prefer Spread
content: Prefer the use of the spread operator ... to call variadic functions. eslint: prefer-spread IMPORTANCE: It's cleaner, you don't need to supply a context, and you can not easily compose new with apply. Copy // bad üëé const x =[1,2,3,4,5]; console.log.apply(console, x); // good üëç const x =[1,2,3,4,5]; console.log(...x); // bad üëé new(Function.prototype.bind.apply(Date,[null,2016,8,5]))(); // good üëç newDate(...[2016,8,5]);

title: Function Parentheses Newline
content: Functions with multiline signatures, or invocations, should be indented just like every other multiline. eslint: function-paren-newline Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(bar, baz, quux){ // ... } // good üëç functionfoo( bar, baz, quux, ){ // ... } // bad üëé console.log(foo, bar, baz); // good üëç console.log( foo, bar, baz, );

title: Prefer Arrow Callback
content: When you must use an anonymous function (as when passing an inline callback), use arrow function notation. eslint: prefer-arrow-callback, arrow-spacing IMPORTANCE: It creates a version of the function that executes in the context of this, which is usually what you want, and is a more concise syntax. Why not? If you have a fairly complicated function, you might move that logic out into its own named function expression. Copy // bad üëé [1,2,3].map(function(x){ const y = x +1; return x * y; }); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((x)=>{ const y = x +1; return x * y; });

title: Arrow Styling
content: If the function body consists of a single statement, omit the braces and use the implicit return. Otherwise, keep the braces and use a return statement. eslint: arrow-parens, arrow-body-style IMPORTANCE: It reads well when multiple functions are chained together. Copy // bad üëé [1,2,3].map((number)=>{ const nextNumber = number +1; `A string containing the ${nextNumber}.`; }); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((number)=>`A string containing the ${number +1}.`); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((number)=>{ const nextNumber = number +1; return`A string containing the ${nextNumber}.`; }); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((number, index)=>({ [index]: number, })); // No implicit return with side effects functionfoo(callback){ const val =callback(); if(val ===true){ // Do something if callback returns true } } let bool =false; // bad üëé foo(()=>(bool =true)); // good üëç foo(()=>{ bool =true; });

title: Arrow Readability
content: In case the expression spans over multiple lines, wrap it in parentheses for better readability. IMPORTANCE: It shows clearly where the function starts and ends. Copy // bad üëé ['get','post','put'].map((httpMethod)=>Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call( httpMagicObjectWithAVeryLongName, httpMethod ) ); // good üëç ['get','post','put'].map((httpMethod)=> Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call( httpMagicObjectWithAVeryLongName, httpMethod ) );

title: Arrow Parentheses
content: Always include parentheses around arguments for clarity and consistency. eslint: arrow-parens IMPORTANCE: Minimizes diff churn when adding or removing arguments. Copy // bad üëé [1,2,3].map(x=> x * x); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((x)=> x * x); // bad üëé [1,2,3].map(number=>( `A long string with the ${number}. It's so long that we don't want it to take up space on the .map line!` )); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((number)=>( `A long string with the ${number}. It's so long that we don't want it to take up space on the .map line!` )); // bad üëé [1,2,3].map(x=>{ const y = x +1; return x * y; }); // good üëç [1,2,3].map((x)=>{ const y = x +1; return x * y; });

title: No Confusing Arrow
content: Avoid confusing arrow function syntax (=>) with comparison operators (<=, >=). eslint: no-confusing-arrow Copy // bad üëé constitemHeight=(item)=> item.height<=256? item.largeSize: item.smallSize; // bad üëé constitemHeight=(item)=> item.height>=256? item.largeSize: item.smallSize; // good üëç constitemHeight=(item)=>(item.height<=256? item.largeSize: item.smallSize); // good üëç constitemHeight=(item)=>{ const{ height, largeSize, smallSize }= item; return height <=256? largeSize : smallSize; };

title: Implicit Arrow Linebreak
content: Enforce the location of arrow function bodies with implicit returns. eslint: implicit-arrow-linebreak Copy // bad üëé (foo)=> bar; (foo)=> (bar); // good üëç (foo)=> bar; (foo)=>(bar); (foo)=>( bar )

title: Class
content: Always use class. IMPORTANCE: class syntax is more concise and easier to reason about. Copy // bad üëé functionQueue(contents =[]){ this.queue=[...contents]; } Queue.prototype.pop=function(){ const value =this.queue[0]; this.queue.splice(0,1); return value; }; // good üëç classQueue{ constructor(contents =[]){ this.queue=[...contents]; } pop(){ const value =this.queue[0]; this.queue.splice(0,1); return value; } }

title: Extends
content: Use extends for inheritance. IMPORTANCE: It is a built-in way to inherit prototype functionality without breaking instanceof. Copy // bad üëé const inherits =require('inherits'); functionPeekableQueue(contents){ Queue.apply(this, contents); } inherits(PeekableQueue,Queue); PeekableQueue.prototype.peek=function(){ returnthis.queue[0]; }; // good üëç classPeekableQueueextendsQueue{ peek(){ returnthis.queue[0]; } }

title: Method Chaining
content: Methods can return this to help with method chaining. Copy // bad üëé Jedi.prototype.jump=function(){ this.jumping=true; returntrue; }; Jedi.prototype.setHeight=function(height){ this.height= height; }; const luke =newJedi(); luke.jump();// => true luke.setHeight(20);// => undefined // good üëç classJedi{ jump(){ this.jumping=true; returnthis; } setHeight(height){ this.height= height; returnthis; } } const luke =newJedi(); luke.jump() .setHeight(20);

title: toString()
content: It‚Äôs okay to write a custom toString() method, just make sure it works successfully and causes no side effects. Copy classJedi{ constructor(options ={}){ this.name= options.name||'no name'; } getName(){ returnthis.name; } toString(){ return`Jedi - ${this.getName()}`; } }

title: No Useless Constructor
content: Classes have a default constructor if one is not specified. An empty constructor function or one that just delegates to a parent class is unnecessary. eslint: no-useless-constructor Copy // bad üëé classJedi{ constructor(){} getName(){ returnthis.name; } } // bad üëé classReyextendsJedi{ constructor(...args){ super(...args); } } // good üëç classReyextendsJedi{ constructor(...args){ super(...args); this.name='Rey'; } }

title: No Duplicate Class Members
content: Avoid duplicate class members. eslint: no-dupe-class-members IMPORTANCE: Duplicate class member declarations will silently prefer the last one - having duplicates is almost certainly a bug. Copy // bad üëé classFoo{ bar(){return1;} bar(){return2;} } // good üëç classFoo{ bar(){return1;} } // good üëç classFoo{ bar(){return2;} }

title: Class Methods Use this
content: Class methods should use this or be made into a static method unless an external library or framework requires to use specific non-static methods. Being an instance method should indicate that it behaves differently based on properties of the receiver. eslint: class-methods-use-this Copy // bad üëé classFoo{ bar(){ console.log('bar'); } } // good üëç - this is used classFoo{ bar(){ console.log(this.bar); } } // good üëç - constructor is exempt classFoo{ constructor(){ // ... } } // good üëç - static methods aren't expected to use this classFoo{ staticbar(){ console.log('bar'); } }

title: Import/Export
content: Always use modules (import/export) over a non-standard module system. You can always transpile to your preferred module system. Why? Modules are the future, let‚Äôs start using the future now. Copy // bad üëé constAirbnbStyleGuide=require('./AirbnbStyleGuide'); module.exports=AirbnbStyleGuide.es6; // ok importAirbnbStyleGuidefrom'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; exportdefaultAirbnbStyleGuide.es6; // best import{ es6 }from'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; exportdefault es6;

title: Wildcards
content: Do not use wildcard imports. Why? This makes sure you have a single default export. Copy // bad üëé import*asAirbnbStyleGuidefrom'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; // good üëç importAirbnbStyleGuidefrom'./AirbnbStyleGuide';

title: Export From Import
content: And do not export directly from an import. Why? Although the one-liner is concise, having one clear way to import and one clear way to export makes things consistent. Copy // bad üëé // filename es6.js export{ es6 asdefault}from'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; // good üëç // filename es6.js import{ es6 }from'./AirbnbStyleGuide'; exportdefault es6;

title: No Duplicate Imports
content: Only import from a path in one place. eslint: no-duplicate-imports Why? Having multiple lines that import from the same path can make code harder to maintain. Copy // bad üëé import foo from'foo'; // ‚Ä¶ some other imports ‚Ä¶ // import{ named1, named2 }from'foo'; // good üëç import foo,{ named1, named2 }from'foo'; // good üëç import foo,{ named1, named2, }from'foo';

title: Do Not Export Mutable Bindings.
content: eslint: import/no-mutable-exports Why? Mutation should be avoided in general, but in particular when exporting mutable bindings. While this technique may be needed for some special cases, in general, only constant references should be exported. Copy // bad üëé let foo =3; export{ foo }; // good üëç const foo =3; export{ foo };

title: Prefer Default Export
content: In modules with a single export, prefer default export over named export. eslint: import/prefer-default-export Why? To encourage more files that only ever export one thing, which is better for readability and maintainability. Copy // bad üëé exportfunctionfoo(){} // good üëç exportdefaultfunctionfoo(){} Put all imports above non-import statements. eslint: import/first Why? Since imports are hoisted, keeping them all at the top prevents surprising behavior. Copy // bad üëé import foo from'foo'; foo.init(); import bar from'bar'; // good üëç import foo from'foo'; import bar from'bar'; foo.init();

title: Object Curly Newline
content: Multiline imports should be indented just like multiline array and object literals. eslint: object-curly-newline Why? The curly braces follow the same indentation rules as every other curly brace block in the style guide, as do the trailing commas. Copy // bad üëé import{longNameA, longNameB, longNameC, longNameD, longNameE}from'path'; // good üëç import{ longNameA, longNameB, longNameC, longNameD, longNameE, }from'path';

title: No webpack Loader Syntax
content: Disallow Webpack loader syntax in module import statements. eslint: import/no-webpack-loader-syntax Why? Since using Webpack syntax in the imports couples the code to a module bundler. Prefer using the loader syntax in webpack.config.js. Copy // bad üëé import fooSass from'css!sass!foo.scss'; import barCss from'style!css!bar.css'; // good üëç import fooSass from'foo.scss'; import barCss from'bar.css';

title: No JS Filename Extensions
content: Do not include JavaScript filename extensions eslint: import/extensions Why? Including extensions inhibits refactoring, and inappropriately hardcodes implementation details of the module you're importing in every consumer. Copy // bad üëé import foo from'./foo.js'; import bar from'./bar.jsx'; import baz from'./baz/index.jsx'; // good üëç import foo from'./foo'; import bar from'./bar'; import baz from'./baz';

title: Iterators
content: Don't Use Iterators. Prefer JavaScript's higher-order functions instead of loops like for-in or for-of. eslint: no-iteratorno-restricted-syntax IMPORTANCE: This enforces our immutable rule. Dealing with pure functions that return values is easier to reason about than side effects. Use map() / every() / filter() / find() / findIndex() / reduce() / some() / ... to iterate over arrays, and Object.keys() / Object.values() / Object.entries() to produce arrays so you can iterate over objects. Copy const numbers =[1,2,3,4,5]; // bad üëé let sum =0; for(let num of numbers){ sum += num; } sum ===15; // good üëç let sum =0; numbers.forEach((num)=>{ sum += num; }); sum ===15; // best (use the functional force) const sum = numbers.reduce((total, num)=> total + num,0); sum ===15; // bad üëé const increasedByOne =[]; for(let i =0; i < numbers.length; i++){ increasedByOne.push(numbers[i]+1); } // good üëç const increasedByOne =[]; numbers.forEach((num)=>{ increasedByOne.push(num +1); }); // best (keeping it functional) const increasedByOne = numbers.map((num)=> num +1);

title: Generators
content: Don‚Äôt Use Generators For Now Why? They don‚Äôt transpile well to ES5. Generator Spacing# If you must use generators, or if you disregard our advice, make sure their function signature is spaced properly. eslint: generator-star-spacing Why? function and * are part of the same conceptual keyword - * is not a modifier for function, function* is a unique construct, different from function. Copy // bad üëé function*foo(){ // ... } // bad üëé constbar=function*(){ // ... }; // bad üëé constbaz=function*(){ // ... }; // bad üëé constquux=function*(){ // ... }; // bad üëé function*foo(){ // ... } // bad üëé function*foo(){ // ... } // very bad function * foo(){ // ... } // very bad constwat=function * (){ // ... }; // good üëç function*foo(){ // ... } // good üëç constfoo=function*(){ // ... };

title: Dot Notation
content: Use dot notation when accessing properties. eslint: dot-notation Copy const luke ={ jedi:true, age:28, }; // bad üëé const isJedi = luke['jedi']; // good üëç const isJedi = luke.jedi;

title: Bracket Notation
content: Use bracket notation [] when accessing properties with a variable. Copy const luke ={ jedi:true, age:28, }; functiongetProp(prop){ return luke[prop]; } const isJedi =getProp('jedi');

title: No Restricted Properties
content: Use exponentiation operator ** when calculating exponentiations. eslint: no-restricted-properties. Copy // bad üëé const binary =Math.pow(2,10); // good üëç const binary =2**10;

title: Use const and let
content: Always use const or let to declare variables. 'var' is a global variables. We want to avoid using the global namespace. eslint: no-undefprefer-const Copy // bad üëé superPower =newSuperPower(); // good üëç const superPower =newSuperPower();

title: One Variable
content: Use one const or let declaration per variable or assignment. eslint: one-var IMPORTANCE: It's easier to add new variable declarations this way, and you never have to worry about swapping out a ; for a , or introducing punctuation-only diffs. You can also step through each declaration with the debugger, instead of jumping through all of them at once. Copy // bad üëé const items =getItems(), goSportsTeam =true, dragonball ='z'; // bad üëé // (compare to above, and try to spot the mistake) const items =getItems(), goSportsTeam =true; dragonball ='z'; // good üëç const items =getItems(); const goSportsTeam =true; const dragonball ='z';

title: Grouping Variables
content: Group all your const and then group all your let. This is helpful when later on you might need to assign a variable depending on one of the previous assigned variables. Copy // bad üëé let i, len, dragonball, items =getItems(), goSportsTeam =true; // bad üëé let i; const items =getItems(); let dragonball; const goSportsTeam =true; let len; // good üëç const goSportsTeam =true; const items =getItems(); let dragonball; let i; let length;

title: Reasonably Placed Variables
content: Assign variables where you need them, but place them in a reasonable place. let and const are block scoped and not function scoped. Copy // bad üëé - unnecessary function call functioncheckName(hasName){ const name =getName(); if(hasName ==='test'){ returnfalse; } if(name ==='test'){ this.setName(''); returnfalse; } return name; } // good üëç functioncheckName(hasName){ if(hasName ==='test'){ returnfalse; } const name =getName(); if(name ==='test'){ this.setName(''); returnfalse; } return name; }

title: No Multi Assign
content: Don't chain variable assignments. eslint: no-multi-assign Why? Chaining variable assignments creates implicit global variables. Copy // bad üëé (functionexample(){ // JavaScript interprets this as // let a = ( b = ( c = 1 ) ); // The let keyword only applies to variable a; variables b and c become // global variables. let a =(b = c =1); }()); console.log(a);// throws ReferenceError console.log(b);// 1 console.log(c);// 1 // good üëç (functionexample(){ let a =1; let b = a; let c = a; }()); console.log(a);// throws ReferenceError console.log(b);// throws ReferenceError console.log(c);// throws ReferenceError // the same applies for `const`

title: No Unary Increments
content: Avoid using unary increments and decrements (++, --). eslint no-plusplus Why? Per the eslint documentation, unary increment and decrement statements are subject to automatic semicolon insertion and can cause silent errors with incrementing or decrementing values within an application. It is also more expressive to mutate your values with statements like num += 1 instead of num++ or num ++. Disallowing unary increment and decrement statements also prevents you from pre-incrementing/pre-decrementing values unintentionally which can also cause unexpected behavior in your programs. Copy // bad üëé const array =[1,2,3]; let num =1; num++; --num; let sum =0; let truthyCount =0; for(let i =0; i < array.length; i++){ let value = array[i]; sum += value; if(value){ truthyCount++; } } // good üëç const array =[1,2,3]; let num =1; num +=1; num -=1; const sum = array.reduce((a, b)=> a + b,0); const truthyCount = array.filter(Boolean).length;

title: Operator Linebreak
content: Avoid linebreaks before or after = in an assignment. If your assignment violates max-len, surround the value in parens. eslint operator-linebreak. Linebreaks surrounding = can obfuscate the value of an assignment. Copy // bad üëé const foo = superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongFunctionName(); // bad üëé const foo ='superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongString'; // good üëç const foo =( superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongFunctionName(); ); // good üëç const foo ='superLongLongLongLongLongLongLongLongString';

title: No Unused Variables
content: Disallow unused variables. eslint: no-unused-vars Why? Variables that are declared and not used anywhere in the code are most likely an error due to incomplete refactoring. Such variables take up space in the code and can lead to confusion by readers. Copy // bad üëé var some_unused_var =42; // Write-only variables are not considered as used. var y =10; y =5; // A read for a modification of itself is not considered as used. var z =0; z = z +1; // Unused function arguments. functiongetX(x, y){ return x; } // good üëç functiongetXPlusY(x, y){ return x + y; } var x =1; var y = a +2; alert(getXPlusY(x, y)); // 'type' is ignored even if unused because it has a rest property sibling. // This is a form of extracting an object that omits the specified keys. var{ type,...coords }= data; // 'coords' is now the 'data' object without its 'type' property.

title: Object / Array creation
content: Use trailing commas and put short declarations on a single line. Copy // bad üëé var a =[ 'hello','world' ]; var b ={'good':'code' , is generally:'pretty' }; // good üëç var a =['hello','world']; var b ={ good:'code', 'is generally':'pretty', };

title: var
content: var declarations get hoisted to the top of their closest enclosing function scope, their assignment does not. const and let declarations are blessed with a new concept called Temporal Dead Zones (TDZ). It‚Äôs important to know why typeof is no longer safe. Copy // we know this wouldn‚Äôt work (assuming there // is no notDefined global variable) functionexample(){ console.log(notDefined);// => throws a ReferenceError } // creating a variable declaration after you // reference the variable will work due to // variable hoisting. Note: the assignment // value of `true` is not hoisted. functionexample(){ console.log(declaredButNotAssigned);// => undefined var declaredButNotAssigned =true; } // the interpreter is hoisting the variable // declaration to the top of the scope, // which means our example could be rewritten as: functionexample(){ let declaredButNotAssigned; console.log(declaredButNotAssigned);// => undefined declaredButNotAssigned =true; } // using const and let functionexample(){ console.log(declaredButNotAssigned);// => throws a ReferenceError console.log(typeof declaredButNotAssigned);// => throws a ReferenceError const declaredButNotAssigned =true; }

title: Anonymous Function Expressions
content: Anonymous function expressions hoist their variable name, but not the function assignment. Copy functionexample(){ console.log(anonymous);// => undefined anonymous();// => TypeError anonymous is not a function varanonymous=function(){ console.log('anonymous function expression'); }; }

title: Named Function Expressions
content: Named function expressions hoist the variable name, not the function name or the function body. Copy functionexample(){ console.log(named);// => undefined named();// => TypeError named is not a function superPower();// => ReferenceError superPower is not defined varnamed=functionsuperPower(){ console.log('Flying'); }; } // the same is true when the function name // is the same as the variable name. functionexample(){ console.log(named);// => undefined named();// => TypeError named is not a function varnamed=functionnamed(){ console.log('named'); }; }

title: Function Declarations
content: Function declarations hoist their name and the function body. Copy functionexample(){ superPower();// => Flying functionsuperPower(){ console.log('Flying'); } } For more information refer to JavaScript Scoping & Hoisting by Ben Cherry.

title: Equals
content: Must use === and !== over == and !=. eslint: eqeqeq

title: if
content: Conditional statements such as the if statement evaluate their expression using coercion with the ToBoolean abstract method and always follow these simple rules: Objects evaluate to trueUndefined evaluates to falseNull evaluates to falseBooleans evaluate to the value of the booleanNumbers evaluate to false if +0, -0, or NaN, otherwise trueStrings evaluate to false if an empty string '', otherwise true Copy if([0]&&[]){ // true // an array (even an empty one) is an object, objects will evaluate to true }

title: Booleans, Strings and Numbers
content: Use shortcuts for booleans, but explicit comparisons for strings and numbers. Copy // bad üëé if(isValid ===true){ // ... } // good üëç if(isValid){ // ... } // bad üëé if(name){ // ... } // good üëç if(name !==''){ // ... } // bad üëé if(collection.length){ // ... } // good üëç if(collection.length>0){ // ... }

title: More Info
content: For more information see Truth Equality and JavaScript by Angus Croll.

title: No Case Declarations
content: Use braces to create blocks in case and default clauses that contain lexical declarations (e.g. let, const, function, and class). eslint: no-case-declarations Why? Lexical declarations are visible in the entire switch block but only get initialized when assigned, which only happens when its case is reached. This causes problems when multiple case clauses attempt to define the same thing. Copy // bad üëé switch(foo){ case1: let x =1; break; case2: const y =2; break; case3: functionf(){ // ... } break; default: classC{} } // good üëç switch(foo){ case1:{ let x =1; break; } case2:{ const y =2; break; } case3:{ functionf(){ // ... } break; } case4: bar(); break; default:{ classC{} } }

title: Ternaries
content: Ternaries should not be nested and generally be single line expressions. eslint: no-nested-ternary Copy // bad üëé const foo = maybe1 > maybe2 ?'bar' : value1 > value2 ?'baz':null; // split into 2 separated ternary expressions const maybeNull = value1 > value2 ?'baz':null; // better const foo = maybe1 > maybe2 ?'bar' : maybeNull; // best const foo = maybe1 > maybe2 ?'bar': maybeNull; Unnecessary Ternaries# Avoid unneeded ternary statements. eslint: no-unneeded-ternary Copy // bad üëé const foo = a ? a : b; const bar = c ?true:false; const baz = c ?false:true; // good üëç const foo = a || b; const bar =!!c; const baz =!c;

title: Mixing Operators
content: When mixing operators, enclose them in parentheses. The only exception is the standard arithmetic operators: +, -, and ** since their precedence is broadly understood. We recommend enclosing / and * in parentheses because their precedence can be ambiguous when they are mixed. eslint: no-mixed-operators IMPORTANCE: This improves readability and clarifies the developer's intention. Copy // bad üëé const foo = a && b <0|| c >0|| d +1===0; // bad üëé const bar = a ** b -5% d; // bad üëé // one may be confused into thinking (a || b) && c if(a || b && c){ return d; } // bad üëé const bar = a + b / c * d; // good üëç const foo =(a && b <0)|| c >0||(d +1===0); // good üëç const bar = a ** b -(5% d); // good üëç if(a ||(b && c)){ return d; } // good üëç const bar = a +(b / c)* d;

title: Multiline Blocks
content: Use braces with all multiline blocks. eslint: nonblock-statement-body-position Copy // bad üëé if(test) returnfalse; // good üëç if(test)returnfalse; // good üëç if(test){ returnfalse; } // bad üëé functionfoo(){returnfalse;} // good üëç functionbar(){ returnfalse; }

title: Brace Style
content: If you're using multiline blocks with if and else, put else on the same line. as your if block's closing brace. eslint: brace-style Copy // bad üëé if(test){ thing1(); thing2(); }else{ thing3(); } // good üëç if(test){ thing1(); thing2(); }else{ thing3(); }

title: No Else Return
content: If an if block always executes a return statement, the subsequent else block is unnecessary. A return in an else if block following an if block that contains a return can be separated into multiple if blocks. eslint: no-else-return Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(){ if(x){ return x; }else{ return y; } } // bad üëé functioncats(){ if(x){ return x; }elseif(y){ return y; } } // bad üëé functiondogs(){ if(x){ return x; }else{ if(y){ return y; } } } // good üëç functionfoo(){ if(x){ return x; } return y; } // good üëç functioncats(){ if(x){ return x; } if(y){ return y; } } // good üëç functiondogs(x){ if(x){ if(z){ return y; } }else{ return z; } }

title: New Line Condition
content: In case your control statement (if, while etc.) gets too long or exceeds the maximum line length, each (grouped) condition could be put into a new line. The logical operator should begin the line. IMPORTANCE: This also improves readability by making it easier to visually follow complex logic. Copy // bad üëé if((foo ===123|| bar ==='abc')&&doesItLookGoodWhenItBecomesThatLong()&&isThisReallyHappening()){ thing1(); } // bad üëé if(foo ===123&& bar ==='abc'){ thing1(); } // bad üëé if(foo ===123 && bar ==='abc'){ thing1(); } // bad üëé if( foo ===123&& bar ==='abc' ){ thing1(); } // good üëç if( foo ===123 && bar ==='abc' ){ thing1(); } // good üëç if( (foo ===123|| bar ==='abc') &&doesItLookGoodWhenItBecomesThatLong() &&isThisReallyHappening() ){ thing1(); } // good üëç if(foo ===123&& bar ==='abc'){ thing1(); }

title: Selection Operators
content: Don't use selection operators in place of control statements. Copy // bad üëé !isRunning &&startRunning(); // good üëç if(!isRunning){ startRunning(); }

title: Multiline Comments
content: Use /** ... */ for multiline comments. Copy // bad üëé // make() returns a new element // based on the passed in tag name // // @param {String} tag // @return {Element} element functionmake(tag){ // ... return element; } // good üëç /** * make() returns a new element * based on the passed-in tag name */ functionmake(tag){ // ... return element; }

title: Single Line Comments
content: Use // for single line comments. Place single line comments on a newline above the subject of the comment. Put an empty line before the comment unless it's on the first line of a block. Copy // bad üëé const active =true;// is current tab // good üëç // is current tab const active =true; // bad üëé functiongetType(){ console.log('fetching type...'); // set the default type to 'no type' const type =this.type||'no type'; return type; } // good üëç functiongetType(){ console.log('fetching type...'); // set the default type to 'no type' const type =this.type||'no type'; return type; } // also good functiongetType(){ // set the default type to 'no type' const type =this.type||'no type'; return type; }

title: Spaced Comment
content: Start all comments with a space to make it easier to read. eslint: spaced-comment Copy // bad üëé //is current tab const active =true; // good üëç // is current tab const active =true; // bad üëé /** *make() returns a new element *based on the passed-in tag name */ functionmake(tag){ // ... return element; } // good üëç /** * make() returns a new element * based on the passed-in tag name */ functionmake(tag){ // ... return element; }

title: FIXME or TODO
content: Prefixing your comments with FIXME or TODO helps other developers quickly understand. Use // FIXME: to annotate problems.# Copy classCalculatorextendsAbacus{ constructor(){ super(); // FIXME: shouldn't use a global here total =0; } } Use // TODO: to annotate solutions to problems.# Copy classCalculatorextendsAbacus{ constructor(){ super(); // TODO: total should be configurable by an options param this.total=0; } }

title: Leading commas: Nope.
content: eslint: comma-style Copy // bad üëé const story =[ once , upon , aTime ]; // good üëç const story =[ once, upon, aTime, ]; // bad üëé const hero ={ firstName:'Ada' , lastName:'Lovelace' , birthYear:1815 , superPower:'computers' }; // good üëç const hero ={ firstName:'Ada', lastName:'Lovelace', birthYear:1815, superPower:'computers', };

title: Additional trailing comma: Yup.
content: eslint: comma-dangle Why? This leads to cleaner git diffs. Also, transpilers like Babel will remove the additional trailing comma in the transpiled code which means you don‚Äôt have to worry about the trailing comma problem in legacy browsers. Copy // bad üëé - git diff without trailing comma const hero = { firstName: 'Florence', - lastName: 'Nightingale' + lastName: 'Nightingale', + inventorOf: ['coxcomb chart', 'modern nursing'] }; // good üëç - git diff with trailing comma const hero = { firstName: 'Florence', lastName: 'Nightingale', + inventorOf: ['coxcomb chart', 'modern nursing'], }; Copy // bad üëé const hero ={ firstName:'Dana', lastName:'Scully' }; const heroes =[ 'Batman', 'Superman' ]; // good üëç const hero ={ firstName:'Dana', lastName:'Scully', }; const heroes =[ 'Batman', 'Superman', ]; // bad üëé functioncreateHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf ){ // does nothing } // good üëç functioncreateHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ){ // does nothing } // good üëç (note that a comma must not appear after a "rest" element) functioncreateHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ...heroArgs ){ // does nothing } // bad üëé createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf ); // good üëç createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ); // good üëç (note that a comma must not appear after a "rest" element) createHero( firstName, lastName, inventorOf, ...heroArgs );

title: Yup.
content: eslint: semi Why? When JavaScript encounters a line break without a semicolon, it uses a set of rules called Automatic Semicolon Insertion to determine whether or not it should regard that line break as the end of a statement, and (as the name implies) place a semicolon into your code before the line break if it thinks so. ASI contains a few eccentric behaviors, though, and your code will break if JavaScript misinterprets your line break. These rules will become more complicated as new features become a part of JavaScript. Explicitly terminating your statements and configuring your linter to catch missing semicolons will help prevent you from encountering issues. Copy // bad üëé - raises exception const luke ={} const leia ={} [luke, leia].forEach((jedi)=> jedi.father='vader') // bad üëé - raises exception const reaction ="No! That‚Äôs impossible!" (asyncfunctionmeanwhileOnTheFalcon(){ // handle `leia`, `lando`, `chewie`, `r2`, `c3p0` // ... }()) // bad üëé - returns `undefined` instead of the value on the next line - always happens when `return` is on a line by itself because of ASI! functionfoo(){ return 'search your feelings, you know it to be foo' } // good üëç const luke ={}; const leia ={}; [luke, leia].forEach((jedi)=>{ jedi.father='vader'; }); // good üëç const reaction ="No! That‚Äôs impossible!"; (asyncfunctionmeanwhileOnTheFalcon(){ // handle `leia`, `lando`, `chewie`, `r2`, `c3p0` // ... }()); // good üëç functionfoo(){ return'search your feelings, you know it to be foo'; }

title: Type Coercion at Start
content: Perform type coercion at the beginning of the statement.

title: Strings
content: eslint: no-new-wrappers Copy // => this.reviewScore = 9; // bad üëé const totalScore =newString(this.reviewScore);// typeof totalScore is "object" not "string" // bad üëé const totalScore =this.reviewScore+'';// invokes this.reviewScore.valueOf() // bad üëé const totalScore =this.reviewScore.toString();// isn‚Äôt guaranteed to return a string // good üëç const totalScore =String(this.reviewScore);

title: Numbers
content: Use Number for type casting and parseInt always with a radix for parsing strings. eslint: radixno-new-wrappers Copy const inputValue ='4'; // bad üëé const val =newNumber(inputValue); // bad üëé const val =+inputValue; // bad üëé const val = inputValue >>0; // bad üëé const val =parseInt(inputValue); // good üëç const val =Number(inputValue); // good üëç const val =parseInt(inputValue,10);

title: parseInt
content: If for whatever reason you are doing something wild and parseInt is your bottleneck and need to use Bitshift for performance reasons, leave a comment explaining why and what you‚Äôre doing. Copy // good üëç /** * parseInt was the reason my code was slow. * Bitshifting the String to coerce it to a * Number made it a lot faster. */ const val = inputValue >>0;

title: Bitshift Operations
content: Note: Be careful when using bitshift operations. Numbers are represented as 64-bit values, but bitshift operations always return a 32-bit integer (source). Bitshift can lead to unexpected behavior for integer values larger than 32 bits. Discussion. Largest signed 32-bit Int is 2,147,483,647: Copy 2147483647>>0;// => 2147483647 2147483648>>0;// => -2147483648 2147483649>>0;// => -2147483647

title: Booleans
content: eslint: no-new-wrappers Copy const age =0; // bad üëé const hasAge =newBoolean(age); // good üëç const hasAge =Boolean(age); // best const hasAge =!!age;

title: Naming Length
content: Avoid single letter names. Be descriptive with your naming. eslint: id-length Copy // bad üëé functionq(){ // ... } // good üëç functionquery(){ // ... }

title: camelCase
content: Use camelCase when naming objects, functions, and instances. eslint: camelcase Copy // bad üëé constOBJEcttsssss={}; const this_is_my_object ={}; functionc(){} // good üëç const thisIsMyObject ={}; functionthisIsMyFunction(){} camelCase Export Usage# Use camelCase when you export-default a function. Your filename should be identical to your function‚Äôs name. Copy functionmakeStyleGuide(){ // ... } exportdefault makeStyleGuide; More camelCase Usage# Use camelCase for variables, properties and function names Variables, properties and function names should use camelCase. They should also be descriptive. Single character variables and uncommon abbreviations should generally be avoided. Copy // bad üëé var admin_user = db.query('SELECT * FROM users ...'); // good üëç var adminUser = db.query('SELECT * FROM users ...');

title: PascalCase
content: Use PascalCase only when naming constructors or classes. eslint: new-cap Copy // bad üëé functionuser(options){ this.name= options.name; } const bad =newuser({ name:'nope', }); // good üëç classUser{ constructor(options){ this.name= options.name; } } const good =newUser({ name:'yup', }); PascalCase Export Usage# Use PascalCase when you export a constructor / class / singleton / function library / bare object. Copy constAirbnbStyleGuide={ es6:{ }, }; exportdefaultAirbnbStyleGuide;

title: No Underscore Dangle
content: Do not use trailing or leading underscores. eslint: no-underscore-dangle Why? JavaScript does not have the concept of privacy in terms of properties or methods. Although a leading underscore is a common convention to mean ‚Äúprivate‚Äù, in fact, these properties are fully public, and as such, are part of your public API contract. This convention might lead developers to wrongly think that a change won‚Äôt count as breaking, or that tests aren‚Äôt needed. tl;dr: if you want something to be ‚Äúprivate‚Äù, it must not be observably present. Copy // bad üëé this.__firstName__='Panda'; this.firstName_='Panda'; this._firstName='Panda'; // good üëç this.firstName='Panda'; // good üëç , in environments where WeakMaps are available // see https://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/#test-WeakMap const firstNames =newWeakMap(); firstNames.set(this,'Panda');

title: No this References
content: Don‚Äôt save references to this. Use arrow functions or Function#bind. Copy // bad üëé functionfoo(){ const self =this; returnfunction(){ console.log(self); }; } // bad üëé functionfoo(){ const that =this; returnfunction(){ console.log(that); }; } // good üëç functionfoo(){ return()=>{ console.log(this); }; }

title: Filename Export Matching
content: A base filename should exactly match the name of its default export. Copy // file 1 contents classCheckBox{ // ... } exportdefaultCheckBox; // file 2 contents exportdefaultfunctionfortyTwo(){return42;} // file 3 contents exportdefaultfunctioninsideDirectory(){} // in some other file // bad üëé importCheckBoxfrom'./checkBox';// PascalCase import/export, camelCase filename importFortyTwofrom'./FortyTwo';// PascalCase import/filename, camelCase export importInsideDirectoryfrom'./InsideDirectory';// PascalCase import/filename, camelCase export // bad üëé importCheckBoxfrom'./check_box';// PascalCase import/export, snake_case filename import forty_two from'./forty_two';// snake_case import/filename, camelCase export import inside_directory from'./inside_directory';// snake_case import, camelCase export import index from'./inside_directory/index';// requiring the index file explicitly import insideDirectory from'./insideDirectory/index';// requiring the index file explicitly // good üëç importCheckBoxfrom'./CheckBox';// PascalCase export/import/filename import fortyTwo from'./fortyTwo';// camelCase export/import/filename import insideDirectory from'./insideDirectory';// camelCase export/import/directory name/implicit "index" // ^ supports both insideDirectory.js and insideDirectory/index.js

title: Acronyms and Initialisms
content: Acronyms and initialisms should always be all uppercased, or all lowercased. Why? Names are for readability, not to appease a computer algorithm. Copy // bad üëé importSmsContainerfrom'./containers/SmsContainer'; // bad üëé constHttpRequests=[ // ... ]; // good üëç importSMSContainerfrom'./containers/SMSContainer'; // good üëç constHTTPRequests=[ // ... ]; // also good const httpRequests =[ // ... ]; // best importTextMessageContainerfrom'./containers/TextMessageContainer'; // best const requests =[ // ... ];

title: Optional UPPERCASE
content: You may optionally uppercase a constant only if it (1) is exported, (2) is a const (it can not be reassigned), and (3) the programmer can trust it (and its nested properties) to never change. Why? This is an additional tool to assist in situations where the programmer would be unsure if a variable might ever change. UPPERCASE_VARIABLES are letting the programmer know that they can trust the variable (and its properties) not to change. What about all const variables? - This is unnecessary, so uppercasing should not be used for constants within a file. It should be used for exported constants however.What about exported objects? - Uppercase at the top level of export (e.g. EXPORTED_OBJECT.key) and maintain that all nested properties do not change. Copy // bad üëé constPRIVATE_VARIABLE='should not be unnecessarily uppercased within a file'; // bad üëé exportconstTHING_TO_BE_CHANGED='should obviously not be uppercased'; // bad üëé exportletREASSIGNABLE_VARIABLE='do not use let with uppercase variables'; // --- // allowed but does not supply semantic value exportconst apiKey ='SOMEKEY'; // better in most cases exportconstAPI_KEY='SOMEKEY'; // --- // bad üëé - unnecessarily uppercases key while adding no semantic value exportconstMAPPING={ KEY:'value' }; // good üëç exportconstMAPPING={ key:'value' }; Use UPPERCASE for Constants# Constants should be declared as regular variables or static class properties, using all uppercase letters. Copy // bad üëé const second =1*1000; functionFile(){ } File.fullPermissions=0777; // good üëç varSECOND=1*1000; functionFile(){ } File.FULL_PERMISSIONS=0777;

title: Accessor Functions
content: Accessor functions for properties are not required.

title: Getters / Setters
content: Do not use JavaScript getters/setters as they cause unexpected side effects and are harder to test, maintain, and reason about. Instead, if you do make accessor functions, use getVal() and setVal('hello'). Copy // bad üëé classDragon{ getage(){ // ... } setage(value){ // ... } } // good üëç classDragon{ getAge(){ // ... } setAge(value){ // ... } }

title: boolean Property
content: If the property/method is a boolean, use isVal() or hasVal(). Copy // bad üëé if(!dragon.age()){ returnfalse; } // good üëç if(!dragon.hasAge()){ returnfalse; } It‚Äôs okay to create get() and set() functions, but be consistent. Copy classJedi{ constructor(options ={}){ const lightsaber = options.lightsaber||'blue'; this.set('lightsaber', lightsaber); } set(key, val){ this[key]= val; } get(key){ returnthis[key]; } }

title: Data Payloads
content: When attaching data payloads to events (whether DOM events or something more proprietary like Backbone events), pass an object literal (also known as a "hash") instead of a raw value. This allows a subsequent contributor to add more data to the event payload without finding and updating every handler for the event. For example, instead of: Copy // bad üëé $(this).trigger('listingUpdated', listing.id); // ... $(this).on('listingUpdated',(e, listingID)=>{ // do something with listingID }); prefer: Copy // good üëç $(this).trigger('listingUpdated',{ listingID: listing.id}); // ... $(this).on('listingUpdated',(e, data)=>{ // do something with data.listingID });

title: jQuery Object Variables
content: Prefix jQuery object variables with a $. Copy // bad üëé const sidebar =$('.sidebar'); // good üëç const $sidebar =$('.sidebar'); // good üëç const $sidebarBtn =$('.sidebar-btn');

title: Cache jQuery lookups.
content: Copy // bad üëé functionsetSidebar(){ $('.sidebar').hide(); // ... $('.sidebar').css({ 'background-color':'pink', }); } // good üëç functionsetSidebar(){ const $sidebar =$('.sidebar'); $sidebar.hide(); // ... $sidebar.css({ 'background-color':'pink', }); }

title: DOM Queries
content: For DOM queries use Cascading $('.sidebar ul') or parent > child $('.sidebar > ul'). Performance Testing Link - jsPerf

title: Scoped jQuery Object Queries
content: Use find with scoped jQuery object queries. Copy // bad üëé $('ul','.sidebar').hide(); // bad üëé $('.sidebar').find('ul').hide(); // good üëç $('.sidebar ul').hide(); // good üëç $('.sidebar > ul').hide(); // good üëç $sidebar.find('ul').hide();

title: Number.isNaN
content: Use Number.isNaN instead of global isNaN. eslint: no-restricted-globals Why? The global isNaN coerces non-numbers to numbers, returning true for anything that coerces to NaN. If this behavior is desired, make it explicit. Copy // bad üëé isNaN('1.2');// false isNaN('1.2.3');// true // good üëç Number.isNaN('1.2.3');// false Number.isNaN(Number('1.2.3'));// true

title: Number.isFinite
content: Use Number.isFinite instead of global isFinite. eslint: no-restricted-globals Why? The global isFinite coerces non-numbers to numbers, returning true for anything that coerces to a finite number. If this behavior is desired, make it explicit. Copy // bad üëé isFinite('2e3');// true // good üëç Number.isFinite('2e3');// false Number.isFinite(parseInt('2e3',10));// true

content: Whichever testing framework you use, you should be writing tests! Strive to write many small pure functions, and minimize where mutations occur.Be cautious about stubs and mocks - they can make your tests more brittle.We primarily use mocha and jest at Airbnb. tape is also used occasionally for small, separate modules.100% test coverage is a good goal to strive for, even if it‚Äôs not always practical to reach it.Whenever you fix a bug, write a regression test. A bug fixed without a regression test is almost certainly going to break again in the future.
